Authors: Mardi M., Arief M., Furinto A., Kumaradjaja R.
Title: Sustaining Organizational Performance Through Organizational Ambidexterity by Adapting Social Technology
Affiliations: Doctor of Research in Management Graduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, West Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mardi, M., Doctor of Research in Management Graduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, West Jakarta, Indonesia; Arief, M., Doctor of Research in Management Graduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, West Jakarta, Indonesia; Furinto, A., Doctor of Research in Management Graduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, West Jakarta, Indonesia; Kumaradjaja, R., Doctor of Research in Management Graduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, West Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This research discussed about the importance of organizational ambidexterity—defined as the balance of focus on exploitation (efficiency) and exploration (innovation) activities—towards organizational performance, especially in the emergence of social technology. There are limited previous empiric researches studied on the effect of social technology adoption towards ambidexterity. We hypothesize that social technology adoption can lead to ambidexterity directly and through rapid absorptive capacity and collectivism-based collaboration. Using quantitative method, this research was conducted to organizations that adopt social technology in various sectors in Indonesia. Data was processed by structural equation modeling (SEM). This research shows that ambidexterity positively affects organizational performance. It also shows that social technology adoption positively affects ambidexterity directly and through rapid absorptive capacity. However, this research does not support the hypothesis that social technology adoption will positively affect ambidexterity through collectivism-based collaboration. This research may give benefits to strategic management literature in finding the robust model to build an ambidextrous organization, especially through social technology adoption. © 2016, Springer Science+Business Media New York.
Author Keywords: Absorptive capacity; Organizational ambidexterity; Organizational performance; Social technology

Authors: Wang G., Polla G., Beng J.T., Kumaradjaja R.
Title: Knowledge management model: The role of absorptive capacity in improving the new product development (NPD) process
Authors with affiliations: Wang, G., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Polla, G., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Beng, J.T., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Kumaradjaja, R., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: The term absorptive capacity (AC) refers to acquiring the external resources to improve innovativeness and performance inside the firm. Since its introduction in year 1990, AC has gained wide popularity for its application in the business world; nevertheless, its application still rare to be found in the vocational schools (known as polytechnics) in Indonesia. In general, the Indonesian polytechnics have lack of AC mechanism in improving their collaboration model with the firms. The article examines the important role of knowledge management (KM) model to improve the AC mechanism inside the state-owned polytechnics. The state-owned polytechnics have mission to support local and national economic corridors, and strengthening the foundation of firms. The article proposes the development of KM model based on the AC studies in the firms, and links them with the efforts in creating new product advantage (NPA). © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Absorptive capacity (AC); Environmental turbulence; Ideation; Motivation; New product advantage (NPA); Potential AC; Prior customer knowledge; Project complexity and risk; Realized AC; Support system

Authors: Tanutama L., Polla G., Kosala R., Kumaradjaja R.
Title: Novel value added services generated from corporate network data
Authors with affiliations: Tanutama, L., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Polla, G., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kosala, R., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kumaradjaja, R., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The competitive nature of Internet access service business drives Service Providers to find innovative revenue generators within their core competencies. Internet connection is the essential infrastructure in the current business environment. Service Providers provide the Internet connections to corporate networks. It processes network data to enable the Internet business communications and transactions. Mining the network data of a particular corporate network resulted in its business traffic profile or characteristics. Based on the discovered characteristics, this research proposes novel generic Value Added Services (VAS). The VAS becomes the innovative and competitive revenue generators. The VAS is competitive as only the Service Provider and its customer know the traffic profile. The knowledge becomes the barrier of entry for competitors. To offer the VAS, a Service Provider must build close relationship with its customer for acceptance. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Competition; Data mining; Traffic profile; Value added services

Title: Recent advances in machine learning for financial markets
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, BINUS University, Indonesia; BINUS Business School, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kosala, R., School of Computer Science, BINUS University, Indonesia; Kumaradjaja, R., BINUS Business School, Indonesia
Abstract: Decision making in financial market is a complex process. A wrong decision can cost millions or even billions of dollars and cause financial catastrophe to the financial institution who manages public funds. We have seen the potential and the promise of AI applications in the financial market for quite a while. However, it is still unclear about the state of the art of AI applications in the financial market today, particularly, with the advancement in machine learning, intelligent agent, and Web 2.0 technologies. This article provides a commentary on the recent advances in machine learning, intelligent agent and other AI techniques in financial market applications, on their successes or failures, and on the future challenges of the machine learning and intelligent agents in the financial market. We observe that utilizing richer data for forecasting market, and developing an integrated framework using Agent-Based Model and Artificial Market for both understanding and forecasting the financial markets would be very promising research areas to pursue. © 2010 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
